titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Richard C. Levin Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Matthew Gorham, Christine Connolly, and Christy Tomecek

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 07:26

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: This collection comprises the papers of economist, professor, and former President of Yale University, Richard C. Levin. The papers document Levin's life and career prior to his presidency of Yale, including research that he performed, expert testimony based on his research, and resulting articles written for scholarly publications. Topics Levin focused on in these activities include deregulation, research and development, vertical integration in the oil industry, and transportation. The collection also contains teaching materials for courses Levin taught at Yale University and activities with professional organizations such as the American Economic Association, National Bureau of Economic Research and the National Science Foundation. Finally there is correspondence related to Levin's duties at Yale and his research. Materials date from 1963 to 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection comprises the papers of economist, professor, and former President of Yale University, Richard C. Levin. The papers document Levin's life and career prior to his presidency of Yale, including research that he performed, expert testimony based on his research, and resulting articles written for scholarly publications. Topics Levin focused on in these activities include deregulation, research and development, vertical integration in the oil industry, and transportation. The collection also contains teaching materials for courses Levin taught at Yale University and activities with professional organizations such as the American Economic Association, National Bureau of Economic Research and the National Science Foundation. Finally there is correspondence related to Levin's duties at Yale and his research. Materials date from 1963 to 1993.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Richard C. Levin Papers (MS 1995). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Richard Charles Levin is an economist, professor of economics, and he served as the longest tenured president of Yale University from 1993 to 2013. His research interests include transportation economics, antitrust law and industrial competitiveness, intellectual propertty, and industrial research and development.

Levin was born in San Francisco, California on April 7, 1947. He graduated from Stanford University in 1968 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in history and subsequently received a Bachelor of Letters degree in politics and philosophy from Merton College, Oxford. Levin earned his PhD in economics from Yale University in 1974 and became an Assistant Professor of Economics at Yale that same year. He was promoted to Associate Professor in 1979, and in 1982 he was appointed Professor in Economics and Management at the Yale School of Management. Before being appointed president of Yale, Levin also served as chairman of the university's Economics Department and the Yale Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.

Levin's presidency of Yale was marked by many accomplishments, including significant growth of its endowment, higher undergraduate admission standards, significant infrastructure development and building renovations, and improved labor relations at the university. Following his retirement as President of Yale in 2013, Levin became the Chief Executive Officer of Coursera, a for-profit educational technology company.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged in five series: I. Correspondence, 1974-1990; II. Legal files, 1978-1993; III. Subject files, 1963-1993; IV. Teaching files, 1966-1992; V. Writings, 1976-1990.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by the creator(s) of this collection for materials they have authored or otherwise produced. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to the papers is restricted until January 1, 2034, or one year after the date of Richard C. Levin's death, whichever comes first, except to the extent that Yale Corporation Miscellaneous Bylaws Section 4 otherwise imposes access restrictions. Tenure evaluations of faculty at any institution and letters of recommendation for students and other persons are restricted for a period of 75 years from the date of the writing or 5 years after the death of the individual, whichever comes first.

Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I comprises correspondence to and from Levin during his time as professor of economics at Yale University. Much of it concerns his research, requests for copies of papers written by Levin, invitations to appear at conferences to present his work, and requests for Levin to review manuscripts. There is also some correspondence between Levin and his students, as well as with Yale University officials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II comprises documents from court cases in which Levin served as an expert witness. Topics include corporate mergers, rights of use in transportation such as trackage rights, and pricing of commodities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III comprises a mixture of materials related to Levin's academic career and interests. Much of it consists of notes, articles and reports pertaining to his research interests. The series also includes materials related to professional obligations, including documents from organizations and workshops in which he participated, and articles he refereed for publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV comprises materials related to classes that Levin taught at Yale University. Materials include lecture notes, course outlines, reading lists, and examinations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V includes drafts of papers for publication in academic journals and related data and notes. There is also correspondence between Levin and journals to which he submitted papers, which include responses to referee reports.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original born digital files, as well as preservation masters, may not be accessed due to their fragility. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist request that they be made. Born digital files cannot be accessed remotely. System requirements include a Manuscripts and Archives computer and file viewing software.
